It has been more than two months since President Trump announced Mr. Scalia would be the next Labor Secretary. 

So, I believe it is fair to vote on Mr. Scalia today, and I would encourage my colleagues to support his nomination.

And @tmsus, who was Senator Kennedy‚Äôs Counsel, wrote, ‚ÄúGene is precisely the kind of person that our country needs in the Cabinet: experienced, ethical, professional, open-minded, fair, and brilliant.‚Äù

Cecilia Madan, a deaf immigrant who Mr. Scalia helped with an employment issue, wrote, ‚ÄúI hope you soon will allow this advocate for justice and fairness in the workforce to have an opportunity to serve the people of the United States-my adopted country-as Secretary of Labor.‚Äù

Former Obama Administration official @CassSunstein wrote, ‚ÄúHis decency is part of what makes him someone who tends to go case-by-case, and to end up where the facts and the law take him‚Ä¶He does not have an ideological straightjacket. He takes issues on their merits.‚Äù

I have received 29 letters in support of Mr. Scalia‚Äôs nomination from small business owners, employers, industry groups, and Mr. Scalia‚Äôs colleagues and mentees, including a number of women and former career attorneys at the @USDOL.

Businesses and workers need a Secretary of Labor who will steer the department with a steady hand. I believe Mr. Scalia has the skills to help continue to grow our economy and help workers gain the skills they need to succeed in today‚Äôs workplace.
From 2002-2003, he served as Solicitor of the U.S. Department of Labor, where he led initiatives to protect workers, reduce unnecessary burdens, and improve enforcement of workplace safety laws.

Mr. Scalia is well qualified to lead the Labor Department. He is currently a partner in the Washington, D.C., office of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, where he has spent the majority of his career working on labor, employment and regulatory matters.

I‚Äôm headed to chair the Senate labor committee‚Äôs Executive Session to consider the nomination of Eugene Scalia to serve as United States Secretary of Labor.

‚Ä¶from a Hispanic immigrant whom he represented on a pro-bono basis, from Cass Sunstein, who worked at the White House for President Obama, and from one of Senator Ted Kennedy‚Äôs former Senior Counsels on the Judiciary Committee.

It is embarrassing to ask well-qualified Americans to be nominated by the President of the United States for an important position and then say, ‚ÄúYou are innocent until you are nominated‚Äù or drag things out for a long period of time.

It has been about two months since @POTUS announced Mr. Scalia would be the next Labor Secretary. This Committee considered President Obama‚Äôs cabinet nominees promptly and with respect, and I trust that the Committee will continue that with President Trump‚Äôs nominees.

Businesses and workers need a Secretary of Labor who will steer the Department with a steady hand. I believe Mr. Scalia has the skills to help continue to grow our economy and help workers gain the skills they need to succeed in today‚Äôs workplace.

Wages are growing at an annual rate of 3.2 percent. African American unemployment fell to 5.5 percent in August ‚Äì and to a record low of 4.4 percent for African American women. And overall unemployment is at a 50 year low of 3.7 percent.
He has served as a guest lecturer on labor and employment law at the @UChicagoLaw and as an adjunct professor at the @UDCLaw.

Mr. Scalia has a distinguished academic background ‚Äì he graduated with distinction from the @UVA in 1985 and from the @UChicagoLaw in 1990 cum laude, where he served as editor-in-chief of the Law Review.

From 2002-2003, he served as Solicitor of the @USDOL when George W. Bush was president. As the Department‚Äôs chief lawyer, he led initiatives to protect workers, reduce unnecessary burdens, and improve enforcement of workplace safety laws.
He is currently a partner in the Washington, D.C., office of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, where he has spent the majority of his career working on labor, employment and regulatory matters.

Today we are considering the nomination of Eugene Scalia to serve as United States Secretary of Labor. Mr. Scalia has broad experience in labor and employment law in both the public and private sectors.

The late Justice Antonin Scalia said, ‚ÄúGenius of the American constitutional system is the dispersal of power. Once power is centralized in one person, or one part of government, the Bill of Rights is just words of paper.‚Äù

After an American revolution against a king, our founders chose not to create a chief executive, but instead wrote the Constitution to separate the power. And, every United States senator has sworn an oath to support that Constitution.
